reviewText: Why is it that so many movie collections like this are NOT among the best films of some actor, yet packaged as though they were? Of the four on here, only "Jailhouse Rock" is really among his best films, although "It Happened At the World's Fair" is a decent movie too but not one of his best. Both of those films have quite good songs in them, with the songs in "Jailhouse Rock" being rock oriented while those in "It Happened......World's Fair" are more ballad and pop oriented. "Charro" often gets very negative reviews, but even though it's not a great production I find it watchable. It's very unusual in that Elvis only sings the title song and no more. At least "Charro" and "Stay Away, Joe" from the late-60s are a departure from the stale "beach movie" types of films Elvis was stuck in by the mid-60s, yet "Stay Away, Joe" is VERY strange and several characters in it are insulting stereotypes of Native Americans. So, if you don't have many of Elvis's movies, start with his best: King Creole,Wild in the Country,Follow That Dream,Jailhouse Rock (Deluxe Edition),Loving You,Flaming Star,Speedway, and Viva Las Vegas (Deluxe Edition). There are also some multi-film sets that include several if his best.

Not only was Elvis a singer that transformed American popular culture, but he was far more talented than most people realize. I am sure that the early T.V. exposure he received was the boost that propelled his career the most but the acting skills exhibited in many of these movies proves his versatility. The wide range of roles would be a stretch for any great actor to pull off, and Elvis did that. He nailed a bunch of awesome performances and I have been enjoying this collection very much. The quality of the video is as good as are the soundtracks and real Elvis fans will be singing along with the King. I think "Charro" is a fantastic movie that stands the "Test of Time" quite well. It is generally the director who has either a clear vision, great actors and a well-written screenplay or a combination of those and with skill, create a memorable movie. Charro has all in abundance. Elvis was perfect in this. I am sure that any film school class that goes over this will agree with me. All four are great of course and "Stay Away Joe" is also a totally great effort with a timeless performance by Burgess Meredith as "Joe's" dad.

Be careful not to scratch either side of discs. Movies will begin automatically shortly if no option is chosen. Disc 1: Jailhouse Rock (1957). MGM. Black & White. Running Time: One Hour, 36 mins. Directed by Richard Thorpe. Elvis Presley's third movie. His was the age 22 during filming. A cocky construction worker, Vince Everett (Elvis Presley), gets into a fight at the bar with a drunken man (Frank Kreig) whom is killed by Vince's boxing. Vince is found guilty of manslaughter and is set to the State Penitentiary. There in the cell, he meets Hunk (Mickey Shaughnessy), a folk singer, who teaches him the guitar. He realizes Vince has a talent for singing. Out of jail, Vince meets Peggy Van Alden (Judy Tyler) whom has recording connections. Also in the cast: George Cisar, Vaughn Taylor, Jennifer Holden, Dean Jones, Anne Neyland, Bill Black, Elaine Dupont, D.J. Fontana, Frank Mills, Scotty Moore, Jeffrey Sayre, Bess Flowers, Cliff Gleaves, George Klein. Option of language and subtitles: English, French, Spanish. The only film Elvis Presley thought he could not bare to watch because of the sudden death of his co-star Judy Tyler who died in a car accident with her husband, July 4, 1957, only 17 days after filming completed on Jailhouse Rock (1957). She was 24. Jailhouse Rock. Jailhouse Rock The Alternate Album. Elvis Presley - Jailhouse Rock COLORIZED VERSION [VHS]. Elvis' next movie: King Creole (1958). Not part of this DVD set. ____________________ Disc 1, Reverse Side: It Happened At The World's Fair (1963). MGM Released April 3, 1963. Running Time: One Hour, 44 mins. Directed by Norman Taurog. Elvis Presley's 12th film. He was the age of 27 during filming. Mike Edwards (Elvis Presley) and Danny Burke (Gary Lockwood) are crop-dusting a potatoe farm from a plane, but what they really have in mind is a couple of "sweet potatoes"...women. Back on the ground, later that night, both men run into some trouble. Danny loses the plane due to an unpaid gambling bet. The next day, they are hitch-hiking on the road and meet Walter Ling (Kam Tong) and his niece, Sue-Lin (Vicky Tiu). They hop in his truck and they all are going to the World's Fair in Seattle, Washington. Also in the cast: Yvonne Craig, H.M. Wyant, Edith Atwater, Guy Raymond, Dorothy Green, Joan O'Brien, Kurt Russell, Mike Mahoney, Bill Quinn, Thurl Ravensscroft, George Cisar, John Daheim, Tom Greenway, John Indrisano, Sid Kane, Wilson Wood, Fred West. Joe Esposito appears as the "Carnival Worker" with the red stuffed dog. Kurt Russell would actually play "Elvis Presley" in the tv-movie, "Elvis" (1979) and did his voice-over in Forest Gump (1994). Kurt Russell also appeared in 3000 Miles to Graceland (2001). Actually filmed in Seattle, Washington - the site of the Century 21 Exposition, the 1962 World's Fair. In-film advertising: Crack Jacks gets a mention, Century 21, NASA. Did Lucy & Desi visit that same trailer park in The Long, Long Trailer (1953)? Elvis would have his own daughter, Lisa Marie Presley, born five years later in 1968. Option of language: English, French. Option of subtitles: English, French, Spanish, Portugues, Bahasa Indonesia and more. Elvis Trailer Gallery. Music: It Happened At the Worlds Fair. Elvis' next movie: Fun in Acapulco (1963). Not in this DVD set. ____________________ Disc 2: Stay Away, Joe (1968). MGM. Released March 8, 1968. Running Time: One Hour, 40 mins. Directed by Peter Tewksbury. Elvis Presley's 27th filmed movie. He was the age of 32 during filming. Joe Lightcloud (Elvis Presley) drives into the country of Sedona, Arizona to help his friend. Joe uses his cadillac to help chase the cattle in, but makes a wrong turn and ends up in the lake. Chester Walking Bear is sending smoke signals of Joe's arrival and that he is sending the cattle herd to his father, Charlie (Burgess Meredith). Joe wants to send his own smoke signal. He is back home and it is time for the Indians to party. Also in the cast: Thomas Gomez, Katy Jurado, Henry Jones, L.Q. Jones, Susan Trustman, Joan Blondell, Quentin Dean, Dick Wilson, Anne Seymour. Del "Sonny" West as "Jackson He-crow". Joe Esposito (Elvis' road manager, bodyguard, friend) as "Man Who takes Joe's Car Away". You might remember Dick Wilson as the grocer in the "Charmin" tv commercials, "Don't squeeze the Charmin". Filmed in Sedona and Cottonwood, Arizona. English Language only. Option of subtitles in English and French. Theatrical Trailer. Music: Stay Away, Joe. Elvis was a married man now, He married Priscilla Beaulieu, May 1, 1967. His daughter, Lisa Marie Presley, was born exactly nine months later in February 1, 1968. Elvis' next movie: Speedway (1968). Not in this DVD set. ____________________ Disc 2, Reverse Side: Charro! (1969). National General Pictures. Rated G. Running Time: One hour, 37 mins. Directed and written by Charles Marquis Warren. Story by Frederick Louis Fox. Elvis Presley's 29th film, third from the last. He was the age of 33 during filming. Jess Wade (Elvis Presley) received a message to come to this western town. When he arrives at the saloon, he finds out it is all a set-up from Vince Hackett (Victor French). A shoot-out begins. Jess separated from this wild bunch over a year ago. Vince didn't like that. So now he is bringing more trouble to Jess. Also in the cast: Barbara Werle, Solomon Sturges, Lynn Kellogg, James Sikking, Paul Brinegar, Harry Landers, Ina Balin, Tony Young, James Almanzar, Charlie Hodge. This movie is not to be confused with Spaniard entertainer, Charo, whom is not in this movie. English language only. Option of subtitles in English and French. Theatrical Trailer. Filmed at Gold Canyon and Apache Junction, Arizona. 2007 DVD release is uncut version, restored and remastered original 35mm film print quality. Elvis' next movies: The Trouble with Girls (1969), Change of Habit (1969). Not in this DVD set.

How can a review of Elvis Presley movies be made? His movies are entertaining with poor acting and with poor plots. He sings well and the movies are so lighthearted that who cares if the acting and script is not the best.

I liked Buddy Holly and did not like the Beatles. But, I like Elvis songs so I enjoy his movies. I am not at all critical because he could not act. John Wayne could not act and neither could Robert Redford. We have a tendency to like what we are supposed to like. Nobody can say that Denzel Washington is a bad actor. I say he is mediocre at best. Now Gene Hackman and Kevin Costner can act. So I rate this Elvis 4 pack at 5 stars because I enjoyed all 4 movies and watched them all the way through. However, it took me two nights on one of them. I got tired.

It Happened at the World's Fair is one of his many throw away scripts that he made so many of, but I enjoy it. Stay Away, Joe, while funny at times, is not his best work.

This is a great collection of Elvis movies. I always love watching Elvis and like having 4 on dvd to watch anytime.

I'm glad there were three other movies along with Stay Away Joe.  I have loved Elvis since 1956, but it was hard to watch this.  Now that I'm not a teenager, I need more substance from a movie.  However Jailhouse Rock and Charro were not in the general mold of most Elvis movies.  Both were great, and to me Charro is his best ever.  It made me think there was something to him besides a handsome face and a wonderful voice.  I believe he could have been a fine actor given a chance at better roles.

I enjoyed this 4 movie set and unlike most Elvis fans, I thoroughly love Charro!..The title song is beautifully done by Elvis, reminiscent of Dean Martin's title song in Five Card Stud...Elvis got to show some serious acting chops in this movie that you rarely got to see..He did just fine in a movie with NO musical numbers. Loved his look and his acting...It is my favorite Elvis movie with Kid Galahad coming in number 2... Jailhouse Rock is a classic and a great movie, but how well you like it will depend on your age..Great movie, but no where near my favorite....Some Elvis fans are drawn to his fluff and nonsense beach movie roles, and others to his character roles.  It happened at the Worlds Fair, a movie worth watching..Stay Away Joe is not one you will enjoy if you are looking for a movie with substance or political correctness..Some beautiful scenery from Sedona, Arizona but not much else..Typical 60's portrayal of the Native Americans and Elvis is playing one...
I love Elvis Presley.  It's nice when you can get 4 movies for the price of one.  I highly recommend this DVD if you're an Elvis Fan.

With the exception of the classic Jailhouse Rock, we have what might be called Elvis' "lost" movies, meaning one quality Hollywood Musical which has been overlooked and two which deserve the overlooking.

JAILHOUSE ROCK (**** 1/2*) is the 1957 must-see: Elvis' acting is a quantum leap forward from his second movie (first starring role in Loving You); the script is excellent and so is the music. We have a serious, credible drama (outside the "rock and Roll movie" genre) with songs. No breaking into a song, a la Bing Crosby, 1935.

IT HAPPENED AT THE WORLD'S FAIR (*** 1/2*) along with Viva Las Vegas, a solid movie actually filmed on location, which has survived decades of opprobium from critics and fans who obviously walked away after the first 3 songs. I purchased this CD set for this movie and my newfound interest in Elvis "movie versions" of the soundtrack album. Fans, if you love Elvis' voice, then dig it on "Take Me To The Fair". Another example of what the engineers could do in drowning out his great closing long notes. There are some outstanding scenes with the child actress - she is excellent. There's no cloying sentiment - the Director was able to evoke real sympathy for the orphaned child, suddenly finding herself in the "adult" world of gambling, booze, and struggle. A very progressive little piece of film history.
Elvis really kicks up his heels here, literally in two of the best fight scenes I've ever seen - too bad someone decided to (unnecessarily) speed up the frames.
I daresay that Elvis is every bit as good in this light flick as he was in the haevy Western drama, Flaming Star. Art Direction is fine, so is the lighting, as Elvis never looked greater.
What stops me ftrom issuing a ***** is that the film has
2-3 too many songs and it does sag in the middle.

STAY AWAY, JOE (**) Here's a marginal ** only in deference to the decision to bring Elvis "up to date" as an actor...getting away from malibu Beach and placing him out in Sedona, arizona. Good Presley performance and terrific songs wasted (I know about "Dominic, The Impotent Bull"). It's been widely and accurately observed that the frivolous stereotyping of Native Americans depiction is a solid reason to....click back to Jailhouse Rock.

CHARRO (*) Sorry, fans, this is an awful movie. Elvis is very unconvincing as  a former gang member who went straight only to be confronted by said aggeregate. The situation of a "pacifist" Sheriff, willing to let his town go down for the sake of Peace, is poorly realized. The well-known backstory is that the Director was told to keep things nice and light - unlike the original idea which would have Presley getting down and dirty. Gotta say it - this one *needed* some silly songs!
I got this for my dad.  I know he appreciated it but I found out that he had already had two of the movies in this 4-pack...so be careful if you are buying this for someone else.
